title: Fantastic forest fungi
description: Today we hiked the beautiful 4 Cedars Trail in Washington. Leaves danced to the ground, plants shimmered in the misty air, birds filled the audible gaps. On these sorts of hikes, the incredible fungi strewn about has always left me wonderstruck. I missed some at the start of the hike, but I decided to research a few that I got pictures of. The first is called Ganodermataceae. The second is Physalacriaceae. And the third, I'm having trouble identifying as a fungus or a disease.

title: Surfing for God (Ch. 3)
description: The hand of Jesus on the first page was so fun to draw.

title: Surfing for God (Ch. 2)
description: Surfing for God is a book on sexual brokenness by Michael John Cusick. I'm only a few chapters in, but it's really sparking my creativity for drawing.

title: The Harvester
description: This is fun! I haven't drawn cars or machines since i was like 12. Its called The Harvester it's a machine for a sci-fi I'm working on. The drawing is kinda, sorta, a little bit what I'm thinking. Revisions to come. It harvests trees using a gripper and a chainsaw that moves laterally. Then tilts them back and they fall into a trailer thing.

title: First day of autumn
description: Reining in fall with some gourd lovin'.

title: I finished Big Magic!
description: Big Magic is Elizabeth Gilbert's beautiful take on creative living. How she personifies ideas sort of blew my mind. Through that, I've noticed the strange relationship/romance I seem to have with ideas. She also has a great no-BS prose that makes me want to hang out with her.

title: My first figure drawings!
description: I've never thought I would be able to draw a body. I always thought it was way too complex. But hey, I really like these! Thanks too my beautiful wife for being very drawable :)

title: Product Collage
description: I've recently done a few of these collages with all the stupidly wasteful mail we get. This is artwork for a sci-fi I'm working on. I have to be super delicate with the placement of the clippings. If I breathe to hard, they fly away.

title: pick-my-people
subtitle: Follow your favorite people
description: I'm tired of social media. It's frustrating to me that there's 100 platforms we check to keep up with people's lives. This project zeroes in on the humans behind the platforms and centralizes their creativity.

title: read
subtitle: Story app
description: I joined a writing group, and I noticed that it was difficult sharing exactly what was new that we had written. So I created this to help.

title: goal-hours
subtitle: Work hours monitoring app
description: Simple app to help myself and my friends stick to a goal number of hours set for our work week.

title: Belltower Window
subtitle: Art studio window
description: Riah (my wife) needed some natural light in her belltower art studio. I said I'd go for it. It took way longer than I thought it would to install, but it worked out!

title: Easel Desk
subtitle: A desk with a built in easel

title: Studio Loft
subtitle: A lounging loft for my wife's art studio

title: joshmk
subtitle: This site
description: At the start of COVID I wanted another project to work on during all the extra time I was saving from not commuting 3 1/2 hours a day. This is what came from that.

title: The Clicket
subtitle: Creature Field Guide
description: Millipede like light bug. 1.5ft long at maturity. By repeating a specific sequence of clicking sounds, the clicket will illuminate for up to an hour depending on maturity. If wrapped around a limb of a host, the clicket can survive as an indefinite source of powerful light on a very small amount of host blood. Despite modern battery and bulb technology being very good, the clicket is still unrivaled in terms of efficiency.

title: The Sham
subtitle: Creature Field Guide
description: Small bird, no more than two inches tall. Swarms together to build elaborate nests extremely quickly. Thousands of years ago it developed a method for camouflaging it’s nests by replicating objects and patterns in the nests surroundings. For example, if there was lots of fallen trees in a wooded area, it may choose to build a nest out of sticks, rocks and mud that looks like a fallen tree. Today, this translates into suburban homedwellers going to bed at night and waking up to a replica of their home next door made of sticks, rocks and mud. Or if you’ve ever noticed a row of mailboxes and one mailbox without a house, that is often the artwork of the Sham.

title: Prevent unnecessary re-render’s in React components
subtitle: The useEffect dependency array

title: The Fwelsh
subtitle: Creature Field Guide
description: Peacock like bird. Unable to fly long distances. Translucent red/orangish feathers. When it sits, it becomes a small fire which can be very useful for camp-outs, but If not tended to, the fire will grow indefinitely and destroy anything in its path. The only way to stop the fire is to ignore it, then the bird will return to its original form and walk away.

title: The Lulem
subtitle: Creature Field Guide
description: A peculiar bubble like creature, that resembles a transparent breast, typically can be found adhering to underwater rocks. Actually a species of sea slug. It can be brought into the home and adhered to a wall to absorb impurities in the air. When pressed, it excreates a clear, thick, honey like substance that’s delicious in most teas.

title: The Stumble-Upon
subtitle: Creature Field Guide
description: When alone in the desert, if rocks are kicked and stumble into each other, a dog-like spirit may enter them. This creature kept ancient Israelites spirits up when they wondered through the desert. The stumble-upon is very playful, and impossible to catch due to it’s ability to shift it’s spirit to nearby rocks when caught.

title: The Snug
subtitle: Creature Field Guide
description: Furry, fleshy, ball. No eyes, ears, or limbs. It feeds off of warmth. Makes a sort of subtle purring noise. Theoretically may never die unless it kills itself or another creature eats it. But it will continue to grow rapidly. Very delicious. Humans have continually tried to make them house pets but often fail due to the animals stupidity. It will tend to roll into the fireplace, onto a burning stove, into a hot bath, etc. they will congregate in large packs and lie like a pile of rocks, feeding off of each other’s warmth and the source of warmth they are on. Yellow snugs are extremely rare.

title: The Ballon
subtitle: Creature Field Guide
description: Large, flat, oval shaped beetle. 3ft in diameter at maturity. Lives on the bottom of rivers. Commonly mistaken for rocks or boulders. It's exoskeleton is stronger than steel. During ancient war times distilled anise was often poured into the shallows of a river, and the ballon would congregate in that area. When picked up, soldiers would place the ballon on their forearm and it’s legs would latch on to the host. Creating an extremely effective battle shield.

title: All women are worth protecting
subtitle: Your ex-girlfriend, your barista, your mom, your friends friend, your mother-in-law, your step-sister, every one of them.

title: I’m now Trump’s OFFICIAL personal assistant!
description: Through a family friend, a young woman receives the honored role as Trump's personal assistant. Or so she thinks.

title: The Swoodle
subtitle: Creature Field Guide
description: Long, skinny, ferret-like creature with shaggy fur. Enjoys climbing to the top of long drapes and staying there for extended periods of time. Often adopted as pets of bald people, due to the creatures love of curling up atop bald heads.

title: The Looth
subtitle: Creature Field Guide
description: Extremely skinny, needle-like fish. Super sharp nose. Approximately 8-10in at maturity. Lies on the sea floor in shallow water with many others. In small bursts, it swims fast enough to swim straight through the body of other fish and even humans. Can be deadly in large swarms. It’s treated carcass is often wound together to create sturdy baskets.

title: The Train Station at the Center of the Earth
subtitle: I wonder what’s there…

title: The Best Things
subtitle: What is says on the tin...

title: The Invention of Sound
subtitle: An old instrument builder living on the edge of a dense forest receives a letter from an unknown source, kicking off an adventure the world has always been waiting for.

title: Beware of Falling Objects
subtitle: How it feels having your home-on-wheels deleted by a tree
ASML
title: Software Engineer
description: Part of an exciting international software development team delivering a tool for deployment and maintenance of next-generation semiconductor lithography machines.
list: Work primarily on the client side (React/Redux)
Delivered many integration (cypress) and unit tests (Jest, Enzyme, React-Testing-Library)
Advocated for experimentation with new waves of latest technology
Key voice in SCRUM ceremonies: stand-ups, retrospectives, plannings, demo’s and refinements
Collaborated across teams and with external service providers to deliver complex features
Represented entire team in demo’s for customers and stakeholders
Deployed to DTAP environment both manually and via automated pipeline (Azure Pipelines)
Provided thoughtful feedback on colleagues work via Pull Requests
Advocated for automation wherever possible
Estimated work and maintained ticket-closing focus to meet deadlines
Greatly enjoyed sharing knowledge via code reviews and mentoring other team members
Internalized business goals for technical decision making
Technically interviewed >30 people to grow team from 2 to 8 developers
Participated in kicking off 2 complementary SCRUM development teams
Delivered small tickets on the Backend (Python, Flask, MySQL)
Interacted with internal IT to maximize security
Used IDE tools VS Code and PyCharm

people.quote: I hired Josh back in 2017 into our continuous improvement team. Josh always displayed eagerness to learn and explore better options. He has a passion for software development, especially when the solutions he is working on make life easier for end-users.

list: Delivered world-wide Skills Management dashboard
Created local OPEX reports, presented to local management and aligned with engineers at headquarters
Traveled internationally to represent greater team

list: Utilized Python and open-source robotics technology like ROS and OpenRave to control a 6ft robot arm using a keyboard, floating mouse and game controller
Analyzed 3D point cloud data from XBOX Kinects
Presented technology to paying customers
